Article.Abstract: Following influenza virus infection, the numbers of mouse TCD8+ cells responding to five different determinants vary more than 50-fold in primary responses but less so in secondary responses. Surprisingly, each determinant elicits a highly diverse and highly sensitive TCD8+ response. Inefficient antigen processing by virus-infected cells accounts for the poor immunogenicity of just one of the subdominant determinants. Overexpressing class I-peptide complexes using vaccinia virus revealed that the poor immunogenicity of two subdominant determinants reflects limitations in T cell responses unrelated to TCR diversity or sensitivity. Despite greatly enhanced expression, the immunodominant determinant is actually less immunogenic when overexpressed by vaccinia virus. Immunodominance is also modulated by determinant-specific variations in the capacity of TCD8+ to suppress responses to other determinants.
Article.ArticleTitle: Dissecting the multifactorial causes of immunodominance in class I-restricted T cell responses to viruses.
Article.Affiliations: Laboratory of Viral Diseases, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892-0440, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: H-2 Antigens;H-2K(K) antigen;Hemagglutinin Glycoproteins, Influenza Virus;Immunodominant Epitopes;NP protein, Influenza A virus;Nucleoproteins;Peptides;RNA-Binding Proteins;Viral Core Proteins
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antigen Presentation(immunology); CD8-Positive T-Lymphocytes(immunology; virology); Cell Line; Disease Models, Animal; H-2 Antigens(genetics; immunology); Hemagglutinin Glycoproteins, Influenza Virus(immunology); Humans; Immunodominant Epitopes(immunology); Influenza A virus(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred BALB C; Nucleoproteins(immunology); Peptides(immunology); RNA-Binding Proteins; Viral Core Proteins(immunology)

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose(s) of ~600 hemagglutinating units

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Splenic as well as peritoneal CD8+ T-cells obtained after Influenza A virus (PR8) infection proliferated in response to peptide (epitope) stimulation. Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells prior to ICS.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose(s) of 10000000 pfu of recombinant Vaccinia virus

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Spleen cells obtained after recombinant Vaccinia virus (contains epitope) inoculation showed lytic activity against peptide (epitope)-loaded P815 cells. Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose(s) of 10000000 pfu of recombinant Vaccinia virus

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Splenic CD8+ T-cells obtained after recombinant Vaccinia virus (contains the epitope) inoculation proliferated in response to peptide (epitope) stimulation. Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells prior to ICS.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose(s) of ~600 hemagglutinating units

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Spleen cells obtained after animals were infected with influenza A virus (PR8) showed lytic activity against peptide (epitope)-loaded P815 cells. Most lytic activity against peptide sensitized-cells is mediated by by VΒ8.1/2+ CD8+ T-cells. Cells obtained on Day 21 were cultured for 7 days in vitro with PR8-infected or peptide-pulsed P815 cells.

The epitope/peptide was acid extracted from PR8-infected P815 cells and fractionated by HPLC. Later the fraction containing the epitope/peptide was tested for its ability to sensitize cells (PR8-infected P815 cells) for lysis by epitope-specific CD8+ T-cell lines. The number of epitopes isolated per cell was estimated and given in the quantitative measurement field, if determined.

Binding of this peptide to Kd was analyzed in the presence of a reducing agent since it contains a cysteine residue. The concentration of peptide required for rescue of 50% of the the Kd molecules was determined. The peptide off-rate was also determined (Figure 1G) and correlates with the affinity constant.
